steps: Inform the Officer of the Watch and Master if they are not already aware of the situation.
Revert to manual steering and manoeuvre the vessel to keep the propeller away from the side on  which the man has gone overboard.
Release MOB marker and SART to the side of man overboard or men sighted
Press the Man Overboard or Mark Position button on the GPS and ECDIS.
Sound the MOB sound signal (three prolonged blasts on the ship’s whistle).
Sound the General Emergency Alarm and inform crew of Man overboard port / stbd side / rescue boat  stations over PA.
Reduce vessel speed and commence Williamson turn.
Additional lookouts posted to keep constant watch for the man overboard or men in the water. If at  night, search lights operated without interfering with safe navigation.
If necessary, sound three prolonged blasts on the ship’s whistle.
Inform the Engineer of the Watch and place the engines on standby (Do not use the M/E Emcy Stop).
Manoeuvre the vessel to rescue the man overboard or carry out a search as given in IAMSAR.
Hoist signal flag ‘O’.
Prepare rescue boat for launching.
Distribute portable VHF radios for communication.
Rig pilot ladder / nets to assist in the recovery, or lower survival suit-clad crew member with rescue  net from ship’s pre-identified rescue point.
Manoeuvre the vessel to create a lee when approaching the man in water.
If man recovered and suffering from hypothermia take all suitable precautions to insulate him before  bringing him into the accommodation and follow hypothermia recovery procedure.
If man is being hoisted by rescue harness, ensure hoisted person is in deck chair position, and not  vertical, to avoid suspension trauma.
Further coordination with third parties after persons in water rescued.
If possible, recover the MOB marker and SART.
Record all actions taken in the Log Book.
Stop VDR recording.
Switch off Wi-Fi and crew internet. Comply with Company’s Social Media Policy.
Conduct Alcohol Test for all crew on duty at the time of incident and record data.
Collect urine samples of all crew on duty at the time of incident for Drug Test (if incident actual  Severity Level 3 and above), sample to offload for shore lab test.

steps: Refer to the following schematics for steering gear failures (at sea or in canal / river / narrow waters).
Reduce speed.
Establish communications with steering flat.
Check and synchronize gyro repeater in steering flat.
Prepare for possible anchoring.
Start bow thruster, if possible, to help steerage at slow speeds.
Stop VDR recording.
Conduct Alcohol Test for all crew on duty at the time of incident and record data.
Collect urine samples of all crew on duty at the time of incident for Drug Test (if incident actual  Severity Level 3 and above), sample to offload for shore lab test.

steps: Let go one or both anchors to prevent further on-set towards bank or bar.
Close watertight doors.
Sound of all cargo hold bilges, cargo, ballast, freshwater and oil tanks, void spaces, cofferdams,  pump rooms and engine room bilges.
Make initial contact with DPA or his alternate.
Conduct Alcohol test for all crew on duty at the time of incident & record data
Maintain contact with Coastal Authority, nearby vessels
Exhibit lights/shapes and make any appropriate sound signals. To switch on deck lights at night
Check the hull for damage, including visual inspection of compartments where possible.
If oil pollution is occurring, take mitigating actions to reduce out flow and report to nearest authority.
Check the nature of the bottom: e.g., sand, soft or hard mud, shell, stones, or coral.
Check the direction, rate of current and stage of tide.
Make a sketch of ship showing the water depths sounded around it with time and tidal conditions and  send to Office.
Determine which way deep water lies.
Determine the condition of wind, sea and / or swell.
Whether hard aground or touching.
Determine the stability and stress conditions.
Check possibility of reducing the draught of the ship, taking into consideration excessive stresses that  may occur.
Tank status: soundings shall be repeated at least at intervals of 2 hours as long as the vessel remains  aground, and an exact record of such soundings shall be kept.
Vessel’s draft: the draught marks should be checked. The time and reading should be recorded.
Examine possibility of using engines to re-float. If possible, make attempt to do so.
Arrange tug assistance if necessary.
Arrange contact with Class ERS for re-floating calculations.
If vessel re-floats, proceed to safe place to perform further checks, including diver assistance.
Stop VDR recording
Switch off Wi-Fi and crew internet. Comply with Company’s Social Media Policy.
Conduct Alcohol Test for all crew on duty at the time of incident and record data.
Collect urine samples of all crew on duty at the time of incident for Drug Test (if incident actual  Severity Level 3 and above), sample to offload for shore lab test.

steps: Close watertight doors and automatic fire doors.
Manual sounding of all spaces - engine room, ballast tanks, cargo holds, cofferdams, void spaces.
Make preparations for abandoning ship.
Assist the other vessel if in life threatening situation.
Is there immediate danger to own vessel or crew? If so, Master should take whatever action to  minimise the danger.
Is it safe for the vessel to remain in the present location? Consider moving to anchoring grounds.
Is the vessel causing danger to other vessels or parties?
Is there any oil pollution? If so, proceed with pollution control action.
Check if there is damage or imminent damage to cargo?
Based on the above assessment, Master should take the necessary damage or pollution control  action.
Determine the need for commercial salvage assistance. Master shall determine if vessel in possible  danger of becoming a total loss before signing an LOF as necessary.
If in coastal waters, contact Local / Port Authorities - Coast Guard, MSA etc.
Check vessel drift.
Stop VDR recording.
Switch off Wi-Fi and crew internet. Comply with Company’s Social Media Policy.
Conduct Alcohol Test for all crew on duty at the time of incident and record data.
Collect urine samples of all crew on duty at the time of incident for Drug Test (if incident actual  Severity Level 3 and above), sample to offload for shore lab test.

steps: Switch to hand steering once emergency generator is on.
Steer vessel away from danger.
Use Aldis lamp with battery to warn other vessels.
Prepare for anchoring if in shallow water.
Conserve power if emergency power is through battery.
Engineers to rectify fault and revert to normal power.

dialogueLists.dialogue: The storm has damaged our main power supply. Captain, please lead the SOP.

steps: Advise terminal; or other vessel (if STS) / bunker barge
Stop all transfer operations immediately, shut valves.
Electrical switches to be activated only if absolutely required
If hose leading upward from the manifold, down-drain the ship’s line to which the hose is connected, if  possible.
Initiate anti-pollution measures as per the SOPEP / SMPEP or other local Response Plans
Inform nearest Authority and other vessels in the vicinity
If liquid is entering the water inform the E/R about the danger of liquid entering the cooling water  intakes.
If evaporating vapour is present on deck, ensure all crew on deck are wearing adequate PPE suitable  for the type of cargo/vapour or ship.
All accommodation access doors should be shut and all ventilation with the exception of closed-circuit  systems to be shut down.
Smoking and naked lights should be prohibited everywhere on the ship and electrical switches  operated as little as possible.
If toxic liquid spillage occurs on deck, fire hoses and water sprays should be used to neutralise its  effects.
On Gas vessels water hoses to be used for dispersing the liquid overboard and to maintain steel  temperatures so that brittle fracture of the hull is avoided.
Water sprays from hoses can also be used to deflect a gas cloud.
If in port, local authorities to be informed.
Emergency Teams to be activated.
If STS operations using chain linked fenders, consider using a foam blanket on any flammable liquid  in the water.
Continuously notify all parties of vessel’s actions / planned actions.
Stop VDR recording.
Switch off Wi-Fi and crew internet. Comply with Company’s Social Media Policy.
Conduct Alcohol Test for all crew on duty at the time of incident and record data.
Collect urine samples of all crew on duty at the time of incident for Drug Test (if incident actual  Severity Level 3 and above), sample to offload for shore lab test.

steps: Stop all transfer operations immediately, shut valves.
Attempt to drain the overflowing tank to other tanks.
Initiate anti-pollution measures as per the SOPEP / SMPEP or other local Response Plans.
Inform nearest Authority (and other vessels in the vicinity only if pollution in water).
If liquid is entering the water inform the E/R about the danger of liquid entering the cooling water  intakes.
If evaporating vapour is present on deck, ensure all crew on deck are wearing full PPE.
All accommodation access doors should be shut and all ventilation with the exception of closed-circuit  systems to be shut down.
Smoking and naked lights should be prohibited everywhere on the ship and electrical switches  operated as little as possible.
If toxic liquid is present on deck and a presenting a toxic hazard to the crew, consider operating the  deck water spray to neutralize it. If in port, ensure local authority informed first.
If STS operations using chain linked fenders, consider using a foam blanket on any flammable liquid  in the water.
Check that liquid has drained completely from any low-level piping such as IG horizontal lines.
Continuously notify all parties of vessel’s actions / planned actions.
Stop VDR recording.
Switch off Wi-Fi and crew internet. Comply with Company’s Social Media Policy.
Conduct Alcohol Test for all crew on duty at the time of incident and record data.
Collect urine samples of all crew on duty at the time of incident for Drug Test (if incident actual  Severity Level 3 and above), sample to offload for shore lab test.

dialogueLists.dialogue:
The tanks are overflowing!
We need to handle it before it gets out of hand!
Do the SOP for it in order to prevent it from getting worse captain!

stepDataLists.callResponse: Deploy containment booms and skimmers to gather any oil that has been spilt, as well as chemical dispersants to break up the oil and absorbent materials to absorb it.
